elements.content: Design, synthesis, and single crystal structure elucidation of modified purine ligands 2-(2-amino-9H-purin-9-yl) acetic acid (L1) and 2-(2,6-diamino-9H-purin-9-yl) acetic acid (L2) and their interaction with certain d10 transition metal ions is described. Copper complex 1 (C28H34Cu2N22O19) afforded a two-dimensional polymeric structure composed of metallaquartets, while corresponding silver complex 2 (C14H20AgN10O8) was formed as a discrete dimer. Complexes 3 (C14H24CdN10O10) and 5 (C14H22CdN12O8), cadmium complexes of L1 and L2, respectively, afforded different coordinating modes, where 3 resulted in a two-dimensional (2D) polymeric structure consisting of metallaquartets and 5 as a discrete dimeric structure, with an octahedral coordination geometry. Complex 4 (C14H13Cl13Hg6N10O8) afforded a unique hexanuclear, 2D polymeric structure, supported by mercury-chloride bridges, presenting as interconnected dimeric, trimeric, and hexameric mercury halide (μ2double, μ3triple, and μ6six) clusters. The potential of halide ions as bridges is interesting. We have also studied the fluorescence properties of ligand L1 and L2 along with complexes 1–5.

Copper complex 1 (C28H34Cu2N22O19) afforded a two-dimensional polymeric structure composed of metallaquartets, while corresponding silver complex 2 (C14H20AgN10O8) was formed as a discrete dimer. Complexes 3 (C14H24CdN10O10) and 5 (C14H22CdN12O8), cadmium complexes of L1 and L2, respectively, afforded different coordinating modes, where 3 resulted in a two-dimensional (2D) polymeric structure consisting of metallaquartets and 5 as a discrete dimeric structure, with an octahedral coordination geometry. elements.content: This manuscript describes structural studies concerning copper, cadmium, and mercury complexes of modified 2-aminopurine and 2,6-diaminopurine ligands. While exhibiting varied coordination modes, these complexes present interesting geometries ranging from discrete dimeric structure to two-dimensional (2D) polymeric structure consisting of metallaquartets. The mercury complex afforded a unique hexanuclear, 2D polymeric structure, supported by mercury-chloride bridges, embedding interconnected dimeric, trimeric, and hexameric mercury halide clusters.

The mercury complex afforded a unique hexanuclear, 2D polymeric structure, supported by mercury-chloride bridges, embedding interconnected dimeric, trimeric, and hexameric mercury halide clusters.

elements.content: Design of metal-nucleobase coordination polymers is an active area of research due to their versatile applications such as surface patterning, magnetism, catalysis, and gas absorption. The embedded coordinating sites and the ease of nucleobases self-assembly through secondary interactions, such as purine–purine interaction, C–H···π interaction, metal-π interaction, and π–π interactions, result in complex supramolecular architectures. Notably, organic carboxylate and amino groups (exocyclic amino groups in the case of nucleobases) actively promote intermolecular hydrogen-bond interactions and contribute toward the stability of structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design of metal-nucleobase coordination polymers is an active area of research due to their versatile applications such as surface patterning, magnetism, catalysis, and gas absorption. The embedded coordinating sites and the ease of nucleobases self-assembly through secondary interactions, such as purine-purine interaction, C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction, metal-π interaction, and π-π interactions, result in complex supramolecular architectures. Notably, organic carboxylate and amino groups (exocyclic amino groups in the case of nucleobases) actively promote intermolecular hydrogen-bond interactions and contribute toward the stability of structures.

elements.content: Selection of ideal nucleobases building blocks and the choice of suitable metal ions lead to the design of desired coordination polymers. Well-defined binding capabilities and coordinating properties of both nucleobases and metal ions act as a driving force to grow complex hierarchical structures, where secondary interactions stabilizes the crystal lattice. However, it is challenging to predict resulting modifications in crystal packing by changing functional groups. Design of coordination polymers could be achieved by keeping a few important points in mind: (a) selection of ligands and coligands with suitable coordinating sites such as carboxylic acid, sulfonic acid, and phosphonic acid groups, etc.; (b) selection of metal ions in such a way that metal ions possess flexible coordination number; and (c) formation of secondary interactions such as intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions, C–H···π interactions and π···π stacking interactions, in order to strengthen higher order supramolecular structure.
elements.clean_text: Selection of ideal nucleobases building blocks and the choice of suitable metal ions lead to the design of desired coordination polymers. Well-defined binding capabilities and coordinating properties of both nucleobases and metal ions act as a driving force to grow complex hierarchical structures, where secondary interactions stabilizes the crystal lattice. However, it is challenging to predict resulting modifications in crystal packing by changing functional groups. Design of coordination polymers could be achieved by keeping a few important points in mind: (a) selection of ligands and coligands with suitable coordinating sites such as carboxylic acid, sulfonic acid, and phosphonic acid groups, etc.; (b) selection of metal ions in such a way that metal ions possess flexible coordination number; and (c) formation of secondary interactions such as intermolecular and intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions, C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, in order to strengthen higher order supramolecular structure.

elements.content: Needless to mention, hydroxyl, amino, thiol, and carboxylic acid, sulfonic acid and phosphonic acid groups are usually used for starting material to design higher order supramolecular structure. In nucleobase compounds, amino and carboxylic acid groups have a vital role in the self-assembling and crystal packing process. Investigation of the coordination behavior of 2,6-diaminopurine (DAP) nucleobase to design supramolecular architectures is fascinating as it not only possesses metal binding sites similar to adenine or 2-aminopurine, but the presence of an extra exocyclic amino group, compared to adenine, might offer another site for coordination, in addition to structure stabilization through hydrogen-bonding interactions.

Investigation of the coordination behavior of 2,6-diaminopurine (DAP) nucleobase to design supramolecular architectures is fascinating as it not only possesses metal binding sites similar to adenine or 2-aminopurine, but the presence of an extra exocyclic amino group, compared to adenine, might offer another site for coordination, in addition to structure stabilization through hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Synthesis of luminescent materials is an important research area due to innumerable potential applications in light emissive chemical systems, analyte sensing, gas storage, catalytic properties, and lasers. We recently documented the synthesis of purine-stabilized green fluorescent gold nanoclusters and their nuclei imaging applications, in addition to synthesis, characterization, design, and luminescence properties of transition metal ion containing purine complexes. Selected d10 metal ions such as Ag­(I), Cu­(II), Zn­(II), Cd­(II), and Hg­(II) provide access to interesting frameworks owing to their flexible coordination properties, which enables them to support higher order polymeric structures. Moreover, d10 metal ions have the potential to significantly perturb ligand fluorescence during complexation. Herein, we report complexation behavior of certain d10 metal ions with 2-aminopurine acetic acid (L1) and 2,6-diaminopurine acetic acid (L2) and their photophysical properties.

Experimental Section

All the solvents were purified by adopting standard procedures. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Bruker Vector 22 FT IR spectrophotometer operating from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Elemental analysis were carried out using a thermoquest CE instrument model EA/110 CHNS-O elemental analyzer.

elements.content:
Ligand L1 was synthesized in three steps by the following procedure ().

Step 1: Synthesis of Methyl-2-(2-amino-6-chloro-9H-purin-9-yl) Acetate (<bold>1a</bold>)

6-Chloroguanine (3 g, 17.69 mmol) was suspended in DMF, followed by the addition of anhydrous potassium carbonate (2.93 g, 21.22 mmol), and stirred at 0 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 2 h. Methyl-3-bromoacetate (2.40 mL, 26.53 mmol) was added over a period of 15 min. The reaction was stirred for 24 h under nitrogen atmosphere at ambient temperature. DMF was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the crude product was purified by column chromatography using DCM:MeOH (98:2) to obtain a yield of 2.89 g (67%). HRMS: (M + H)+ calculated: 242.0445, observed: 242.0415. 1H NMR: (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS) δ (ppm) 3.66 (s, 3H, O–CH3), 4.96 (s, 2H, -NCH2-), 6.95 (s, 2H, N2–H), 8.05 (s, 1H, C8–H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS); δ (ppm) 44.44, 53.07, 123.42, 143.96, 149.99, 154.75, 160.47, 168.71.

elements.content:
Ligand L2 was synthesized in two steps by the following procedure ().

Step 1: Synthesis of Methyl 2-(2,6-Diamino-9<italic>H</italic>-purin-9-yl) Acetate (<bold>2a</bold>)

2,6-Diaminopurine (3 g, 19.98 mmol) was suspended in dry DMF followed by the addition of sodium hydride (0.683 g, 29.97 mmol) and stirred under a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. Methyl-3-bromoacetate (3.33 mL, 29.97 mmol) was added over a period of 15 min to the reaction mixture. The reaction was continued for 48 h under nitrogen atmosphere at ambient temperature. The resulting reaction mixture was evaporated under reduced pressure and further purified by column chromatography, to obtain a yield of 2.80 g (63%). HRMS: (L + H)+ calculated: 223.0943, observed: 223.0941. 1H NMR: (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS) δ (ppm) 3.65 (s, 3H, O–CH3), 4.83 (s, 2H. -N–CH2-), 5.80 (s, 2H, −N6-H2), 6.67 (s, 2H, −N2-H2) 7.64­(s, 1H, C8–H), 13C NMR: (125 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS); δ (ppm) 43.89, 52.84, 113.17, 138.25, 152.47, 156.64, 160.94, 169.29.

The white color precipitate so obtained was dissolved by adding a few drops of 1 N HCl. This solution was filtered and kept unperturbed for crystallization. The colorless crystals were grown by slow evaporation within 2 weeks (0.28 g, 52%). HRMS: (L1 + H)+ calculated: 194.0678, observed: 194.0672. (L1 + Hg + Cl + H)+ calculated: 431.0073, observed: 431.0900. Anal. Calcd (%) for C14H13Cl13Hg6N10O4: C 8.20, H 0.64, N 6.83; Found: C 7.98, H 0.30, N 6.96.; IR (KBr, v/cm-1): 3330, 3102, 1739, 1665, 1648, 1528, 1436, 1351, 1300, 1087, 974, 776, 676, 626.

elements.content: Suitable crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were mounted on a CCD Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer. Data were collected at 100(2) K using graphite monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λα = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined (SHELXL 97) by full matrix least-squares procedures on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were included in idealized positions and were refined according to the riding model. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The O–H and N–H protons were included from the electron density map and refined isotropically. Details of the data collection and refinement parameters of (1–5) are given in . The crystallographic figures have been generated using Diamond 3.2g. The contribution of all hydrogen atoms has been incorporated in both empirical formulas and formula weights of the complexes. The “B” alert in complex 4 indicates that “coordinates do not form properly connected set”, which is common for coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination and Refinement

Suitable crystals for single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were mounted on a CCD Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer. Data were collected at 100(2) K using graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λα = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined (SHELXL 97) by full matrix least-squares procedures on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were included in idealized positions and were refined according to the riding model. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The O-H and N-H protons were included from the electron density map and refined isotropically. Details of the data collection and refinement parameters of (1-5) are given in . The crystallographic figures have been generated using Diamond 3.2g. The contribution of all hydrogen atoms has been incorporated in both empirical formulas and formula weights of the complexes. The "B" alert in complex 4 indicates that "coordinates do not form properly connected set", which is common for coordination polymers.

Complex 1 crystals were grown from methanolic solution of ligand L1 with Cu­(NO3)2 (1:2), under slightly acidic conditions, by slow evaporation. Crystal data refinement suggested that 1 crystallized as a monoclinic crystal system in “P21/c” space group. The unit cell consisted of two ligand molecules coordinated to a copper­(II) ion via N7 nitrogen, three water molecules (one water molecule coordinate to copper­(II) ion and other two water molecules are noncoordinated), and a nitrate anion (a). The overall charge of this complex was neutralized by a noncoordinating nitrate ion and a carboxylate ion from the ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Description of Complex 1 

Complex 1 crystals were grown from methanolic solution of ligand L1 with Cu(NO3)2 (1:2), under slightly acidic conditions, by slow evaporation. Crystal data refinement suggested that 1 crystallized as a monoclinic crystal system in "P21/c" space group. The unit cell consisted of two ligand molecules coordinated to a copper(II) ion via N7 nitrogen, three water molecules (one water molecule coordinate to copper(II) ion and other two water molecules are noncoordinated), and a nitrate anion (a). The overall charge of this complex was neutralized by a noncoordinating nitrate ion and a carboxylate ion from the ligand.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit cell of 1 (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity), (b) 2D crystal lattice of the complex 1, (c) metallaquartets of complex 1 (with Cu–Cu distances in Å).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit cell of 1 (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity), (b) 2D crystal lattice of the complex 1, (c) metallaquartets of complex 1 (with Cu-Cu distances in Å).

elements.content: This asymmetric unit, when grown further, afforded a 2D-metal-coordinated lattice where it was clearly evident that Cu (II) ion is coordinated to three oxygens from two carboxylate ions of different ligand units (b). The carboxylate ions bind to copper ions in two different coordination modes: in a monodentate fashion (O3) and in bidentate fashion (O7 and O8) resulting in a distorted octahedral geometry around Cu (II) ions (b). Thorough investigation of this 2D crystal lattice exhibited interesting metallaquartet formation. In this metallaquartet, two types of adjacent Cu–Cu distances were noticed, i.e., 7.70 and 8.03 Å (c).
elements.clean_text: This asymmetric unit, when grown further, afforded a 2D-metal-coordinated lattice where it was clearly evident that Cu (II) ion is coordinated to three oxygens from two carboxylate ions of different ligand units (b). The carboxylate ions bind to copper ions in two different coordination modes: in a monodentate fashion (O3) and in bidentate fashion (O7 and O8) resulting in a distorted octahedral geometry around Cu (II) ions (b). Thorough investigation of this 2D crystal lattice exhibited interesting metallaquartet formation. In this metallaquartet, two types of adjacent Cu-Cu distances were noticed, i.e., 7.70 and 8.03 Å (c).

elements.content: This structure was stabilized by secondary interactions (purine–purine interactions) through the Watson–Crick face of purine ligands, N2–H2A···N3, with a bond distance of 2.22 Å, affording a 3D polymeric structure (). The crystal structure is further stabilized by extended π···π interactions between two purine six-membered rings, with an approximate distance of 3.64 Å (). Close study of crystal lattice exhibited that the nitrate counteranion was involved in secondary interactions with exocyclic amino group of ligand L1 (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: This structure was stabilized by secondary interactions (purine-purine interactions) through the Watson-Crick face of purine ligands, N2-H2A⋅⋅⋅N3, with a bond distance of 2.22 Å, affording a 3D polymeric structure (). The crystal structure is further stabilized by extended π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between two purine six-membered rings, with an approximate distance of 3.64 Å (). Close study of crystal lattice exhibited that the nitrate counteranion was involved in secondary interactions with exocyclic amino group of ligand L1 (Figure S1).

elements.content: The crystal structure of complex 2 was grown from a methanolic solution of ligand L1 and silver perchlorate (1:2), in the presence of a few drops of ammonium hydroxide, by slow evaporation over a 10 day period. Refinement of crystal data suggested that 2 crystallized in a triclinic system with “P1̅” space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 was composed of a silver­(I) ion coordinated to L1 via N7 atom and was neutralized by its carboxylate ion and two noncoordinated water molecules (a). Interestingly, silver ions did not coordinate to carboxylate oxygen atoms of L1, but to two imino N7 nitrogen atoms from two purine rings affording a linear geometry (b).

Crystal Description of Complex 2 

The crystal structure of complex 2 was grown from a methanolic solution of ligand L1 and silver perchlorate (1:2), in the presence of a few drops of ammonium hydroxide, by slow evaporation over a 10 day period. Refinement of crystal data suggested that 2 crystallized in a triclinic system with "P1̅" space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 was composed of a silver(I) ion coordinated to L1 via N7 atom and was neutralized by its carboxylate ion and two noncoordinated water molecules (a). Interestingly, silver ions did not coordinate to carboxylate oxygen atoms of L1, but to two imino N7 nitrogen atoms from two purine rings affording a linear geometry (b).

elements.content: L1 reacted with Cd­(NO3)2 to form cadmium complex 3 under slightly basic conditions, and corresponding colorless crystals were grown from aqueous methanolic solution in 10 days. Complex 3 crystallized in a monoclinic system with the “P21/n” space group, where the unit cell composed of one carboxylate ligand coordinated to a Cd­(II) ion and three water molecules (one water molecule coordinated to cadmium atom and other two noncoordinated to cadmium atom) (a). The Cd­(II) ion exhibited hexa-coordination by employing two oxygens and two imino nitrogens from L1 and two coordinated water molecules, thereby presenting an octahedral geometry (b), with the carboxylate ion coordinated to the Cd­(II) ion in a monodentate fashion.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Description of Complex 3 

 L1 reacted with Cd(NO3)2 to form cadmium complex 3 under slightly basic conditions, and corresponding colorless crystals were grown from aqueous methanolic solution in 10 days. Complex 3 crystallized in a monoclinic system with the "P21/n" space group, where the unit cell composed of one carboxylate ligand coordinated to a Cd(II) ion and three water molecules (one water molecule coordinated to cadmium atom and other two noncoordinated to cadmium atom) (a). The Cd(II) ion exhibited hexa-coordination by employing two oxygens and two imino nitrogens from L1 and two coordinated water molecules, thereby presenting an octahedral geometry (b), with the carboxylate ion coordinated to the Cd(II) ion in a monodentate fashion.

elements.content: Thorough investigation of the crystal structure revealed a 2D grid-like coordination polymer composed of novel cadmium-mediated metallacycles (d). Each metallacycle resembles a rhomboid arrangement with cadmium ions at vertices and purine carboxylate ligands L1 as the sides of a rhombus (d). The cadmium metal ions are equispaced, and the Cd–Cd distance is found to be 9.66 Å (d). Clear insight into crystal lattice revealed that ligand L1 coordinated to central metal ions in a bidentate mode via N7 and O2 (d). Interestingly, two adjacent polymeric layers interacted with each other through hydrogen bonding interactions (N2–H···N1), resulting in a 3D supramolecular lattice structure (a). The observed hydrogen bonding distance between N2–H and N1 atom was 2.12 Å (b), and the bond angle between them was 172.01°. Extensive secondary π···π interactions were observed between two neighboring purine six-membered rings, with a separation of 3.72 Å (b).

elements.content: Several reports in literature have described a variety of mononuclear mercury­(II) complexes with varying coordination numbers exhibiting disparate geometries. Formation of a four-membered doubly bridged mercury cluster [μ2-(HgCl)2] is very common in halogen-mercurate­(II) complexes, while a triply bridged mercury complex of [μ3-(HgCl)3] type has rarely been reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Description of Complex 4 

Several reports in literature have described a variety of mononuclear mercury(II) complexes with varying coordination numbers exhibiting disparate geometries. Formation of a four-membered doubly bridged mercury cluster [μ2-(HgCl)2] is very common in halogen-mercurate(II) complexes, while a triply bridged mercury complex of [μ3-(HgCl)3] type has rarely been reported in the literature.

elements.content: Complex 4 was prepared by reacting ligand L1 with HgCl2 (1:3) under slightly acidic conditions, which yielded colorless crystals grown from its methanolic solution in 14 days. This crystal belonged to the triclinic system with “P1̅” space group. Unit cell of the crystal lattice consisted of six Hg­(II) ions, 14 chloride ions, and two L1 units, with the overall charge being neutralized by chloride ions and carboxylate ions (a).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit when grown extended in a 2D-polymeric network comprising of two different types of mercuric cluster units: [Hg6Cl13] (type A: pink) and [Hg6Cl13] (type B: gray) (b). The overall lattice displays three types of μ-chlorido ions: μ2‑double, μ3‑triple, and μ6‑six bridging between mercury­(II) ions. Each type of cluster possesses μ2 chloride ions bridged between two Hg­(II) ions and a μ6-chlorido core. Both of these clusters are arranged alternatively and interconnected through μ3‑triple mercury-chloride bridges, marked by blue arrows in b. L1 exhibited bidentate coordination via N7 nitrogen atom from purine ring and O1 atom from the pendant carboxylate group (b).

elements.content: Careful insights into type A cluster [Hg6Cl13] revealed the presence of a μ6-chlorido core, where the central chloride ion is coordinated to six Hg­(II) ions in an octahedral environment exhibiting a star-shaped structure with the Hg–Cl–Hg bond angle of 180° (). Each Hg­(II) ion is further coordinated to six ligand molecules forming the periphery of the cluster unit and eight bridged chloride ions. Interestingly, this cluster contained three sets of crystallographically unique Hg­(II) ions. Hg1 and Hg3 display a penta-coordinated distorted square pyramidal geometry wherein Hg1 coordinated to a ligand molecule via N7 atom and four bridged chloride ions, while Hg3 coordinated to three bridged and a terminal chloride ion, in addition to N7 atom of the purine ring (); Hg2 exhibited a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to O2 from the carboxylate side chain, four bridged chloride ions and a terminal chloride ion (). The bridging Hg–Cl bonds are nearly equivalent and are significantly longer than terminal mercury-halides bonds (Supporting Information, Table S2).

elements.content: Thorough analysis into Type B cluster [Hg6Cl13] revealed a propeller-like structure having a similar μ6-chlorido core, with the central chloride ion coordinated to six Hg­(II) ions showing an octahedral geometry ( and ). It is interesting to note that the cluster unit gets stabilized with the help of type ‘A’ cluster through μ3-chlorido bridge, thereby rendering stability to the overall lattice (). Type ‘B’ cluster is composed of 12 pairs of μ2‑double chlorido bridge, one μ6‑six chlorido bridge, and two sets of crystallographically unique mercury ions (). One set of mercury ions represented by Hg4 and Hg6 has a similar distorted octahedral environment where each Hg­(II) ion is coordinated to five μ2-bridged chloride ions and a μ3-chloride ion, whereas the other set of mercury ions Hg5 coordinated to five bridged chloride ions resulting in a penta-coordinated, distorted square pyramidal geometry (). Selected bond distances and bond angles are provided in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Block-shaped colorless small-sized crystals were grown from a methanolic solution of ligand L2 and cadmium nitrate (1:2) in the presence of a few drops of ammonium hydroxide solution by slow evaporation. X-ray data suggested that cadmium complex 5 crystallized in triclinic space group “P1̅”. The asymmetric unit cell of complex 5 consisted of one L2 molecule coordinated to a Cd­(II) ion via O2 oxygen and two coordinated water molecules (a). Overall coordination of the Cd­(II) ion involved participation of two oxygens from two carboxylate ions of two different ligand units and four coordinated water molecules, resulting in an octahedral geometry around Cd­(II) ions (b). It is noticed that N7 nitrogen of L2 did not participate in complexation, which may be attributed to persistent steric hindrance at the N7 site.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Description of Complex 5 

Block-shaped colorless small-sized crystals were grown from a methanolic solution of ligand L2 and cadmium nitrate (1:2) in the presence of a few drops of ammonium hydroxide solution by slow evaporation. X-ray data suggested that cadmium complex 5 crystallized in triclinic space group "P1̅". The asymmetric unit cell of complex 5 consisted of one L2 molecule coordinated to a Cd(II) ion via O2 oxygen and two coordinated water molecules (a). Overall coordination of the Cd(II) ion involved participation of two oxygens from two carboxylate ions of two different ligand units and four coordinated water molecules, resulting in an octahedral geometry around Cd(II) ions (b). It is noticed that N7 nitrogen of L2 did not participate in complexation, which may be attributed to persistent steric hindrance at the N7 site.

elements.content: In complex 3, th eN7 binding site of ligand L1 actively participated in coordination to the cadmium­(II) ion. The presence of an extra amino group in ligand L2 perhaps restricts the binding ability of N7 nitrogen toward the cadmium­(II) ion and a potential carboxylate group succeeds in binding the metal ion. Interestingly, hydrogen bonding interactions observed in complex 5 follow a pattern slightly different from that of complex 3 due to the presence of an extra NH2 group. Here the crystal lattice appears as an ML2 dimer (c), which leads to higher order polymeric chains through secondary interactions ().

elements.content: Investigation of complex 5 revealed purine–purine hydrogen bonding interaction through the Watson–Crick face resulting in a 1D zigzag polymeric structure (c). Additionally, interactions between carboxylate oxygens and exocyclic amino groups with a distance of 2.16 Å were also observed to stabilize the crystal network (d). Purine rings were observed supporting π–π stacking interactions with a separation of 3.9 Å (d), promoting stabilization of the crystal lattice. The crystal lattice of complex 5 is stabilized by strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions leading to a 3D polymeric structure ().

elements.content: 2-AP is known serve as a fluorescent nucleobase in biochemical studies. Chemical modifications of 2-AP and its interaction with metal ions afford interesting supramolecular architectures with variable photophysical properties. Consequently, fluorescence properties of ligands L1 and L2 and all complexes 1–5 were determined in solution state at room temperature (). Ligand as well as complexes 1–3 and complex 5 exhibited broad photoluminescence spectra with a maximum at 371 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. All metal complexes (1–5) displayed reduced intensity in their respective emission spectra compared to ligand L1.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Study

2-AP is known serve as a fluorescent nucleobase in biochemical studies. Chemical modifications of 2-AP and its interaction with metal ions afford interesting supramolecular architectures with variable photophysical properties. Consequently, fluorescence properties of ligands L1 and L2 and all complexes 1-5 were determined in solution state at room temperature (). Ligand as well as complexes 1-3 and complex 5 exhibited broad photoluminescence spectra with a maximum at 371 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. All metal complexes (1-5) displayed reduced intensity in their respective emission spectra compared to ligand L1.

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of L1 along with complexes 1–4. (b) Fluorescence emission spectra of ligand L2 along with 5.
elements.clean_text: 12  (a) Emission spectra of L1 along with complexes 1-4. (b) Fluorescence emission spectra of ligand L2 along with 5.

elements.content: Introduction of transition-guest metal ion and its interaction with ligand L1 may follow some nonradiative energy loss process, such as ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) or d–d transitions or ligand to metal electron transfer or spin–orbit coupling process resulting fluorescence quenching. Ligand L2 as well as complexes 5 exhibited broad emission spectra with a maximum at 365 and 355 nm respectively, upon excitation at 285 nm. The emission spectra of complex 5 appeared to be slightly blue-shifted compared to ligand L2, implying the energy level perturbation through complexation. There is a sharp fluorescence quenching in complex 5. This quenching could be attributed to the metal complexes, affecting the π–π stacking interaction and facilitating nonradiative energy loss processes.

elements.content: We have reported five metal (Group 11 and Group 12) complexes by using 2-aminopurine acetic acid (L1) and 2,6-diaminopurine acetic acid (L2). We discussed metallaquartets formation in complex 1 and complex 3 with Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) metal ions and compared binding ability of 2-aminopurine acetic acid and 2,6-diaminopurine acetic acid with cadmium ions, under similar reaction conditions. Most of complexes reported here exhibit purine–purine interaction. Remarkably, ligand L1 reacts with HgCl2 to form a unique hexanuclear mercury cluster with an intricate mercury-chloride bridge. Structural plurality of complexes, along with their photophysical properties, clearly prove that nucleobases could serve as versatile building blocks for coordination polymers with a range of metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have reported five metal (Group 11 and Group 12) complexes by using 2-aminopurine acetic acid (L1) and 2,6-diaminopurine acetic acid (L2). We discussed metallaquartets formation in complex 1 and complex 3 with Cu(II) and Cd(II) metal ions and compared binding ability of 2-aminopurine acetic acid and 2,6-diaminopurine acetic acid with cadmium ions, under similar reaction conditions. Most of complexes reported here exhibit purine-purine interaction. Remarkably, ligand L1 reacts with HgCl2 to form a unique hexanuclear mercury cluster with an intricate mercury-chloride bridge. Structural plurality of complexes, along with their photophysical properties, clearly prove that nucleobases could serve as versatile building blocks for coordination polymers with a range of metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
Ligand L1 was synthesized in three steps by the following procedure ().

Step 1: Synthesis of Methyl-2-(2-amino-6-chloro-9H-purin-9-yl) Acetate (<bold>1a</bold>)

6-Chloroguanine (3 g, 17.69 mmol) was suspended in DMF, followed by the addition of anhydrous potassium carbonate (2.93 g, 21.22 mmol), and stirred at 0 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 2 h. Methyl-3-bromoacetate (2.40 mL, 26.53 mmol) was added over a period of 15 min. The reaction was stirred for 24 h under nitrogen atmosphere at ambient temperature. DMF was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the crude product was purified by column chromatography using DCM:MeOH (98:2) to obtain a yield of 2.89 g (67%). HRMS: (M + H)+ calculated: 242.0445, observed: 242.0415. 1H NMR: (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS) δ (ppm) 3.66 (s, 3H, O–CH3), 4.96 (s, 2H, -NCH2-), 6.95 (s, 2H, N2–H), 8.05 (s, 1H, C8–H). 13C NMR (125 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS); δ (ppm) 44.44, 53.07, 123.42, 143.96, 149.99, 154.75, 160.47, 168.71.

Step 2: Synthesis of Methyl-2-(2-amino-9<italic>H</italic>-purin-9-yl) acetate (<bold>1b</bold>)

Compound 1a (2 g, 8.27 mmol) was dissolved in dry methanol followed by the addition of ammonium formate (2.08 g, 33.10 mmol) and a catalytic amount palladium-charcoal (0.02 g) and stirred. The reaction was completed in 4 h, and whereafter the reaction mixture was filtered through a cellite pad for the removal of colored impurities. Methanolic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and further purified by column chromatography, to obtain a yield of 1.45 g (84%). HRMS: (M + H)+ calculated: 208.0834, observed: 208.0834. 1H NMR: (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS) δ (ppm) 3.65 (s, 3H, -OCH3), 4.96 (s, 2H, -CH2−), 6.53 (s, 2H, N2–H), 8.01 (s, 1H, C8–H), 8.55 (s, 1H, C6–H). 13C NMR: (125 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS); δ (ppm) 44.44, 53.06, 123.44, 143.96, 150.00, 154.75, 160.47, 168.70.

Step 3: Synthesis of 3-(2-Amino-9<italic>H</italic>-purin-9-yl) acetic acid (<bold>L1</bold>)

1b methyl ester (0.5 g, 2.41 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (30 mL), 1 N NaOH solution (500 μL) was added over a period of 30 min, and the solution was stirred for 1 h. It was neutralized by using 1 N HCl, and whereafter a white precipitate was obtained. It was filtered and dried under high vacuum, to obtain a yield of 0.42 g (90%). HRMS: (M + H)+ calculated: 194.0678, observed: 194.0679. 1H NMR: (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 25 °C, TMS) δ (ppm) 4.82 (s, 2H. -NCH2-), 6.52 (s, 2H, N2–H), 7.99 (s, 1H, C8–H), 8.54­(s, 1H, C6–H), 13C NMR: (125 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C, TMS); δ (ppm) 47.11, 118.67, 142.69, 150.21, 152.49, 156.21, 170.11. IR (KBr, v/cm–1): 3372, 3123, 2981, 1656, 1599, 1579, 1533, 1436, 1386, 1295, 1152, 99, 932, 780, 645, 625.

Synthesis of 2-(2,6-Diamino-9<italic>H</italic>-purin-9-yl) Acetic Acid (<bold>L2</bold>)

Ligand L2 was synthesized in two steps by the following procedure ().

Step 1: Synthesis of Methyl 2-(2,6-Diamino-9<italic>H</italic>-purin-9-yl) Acetate (<bold>2a</bold>)

2,6-Diaminopurine (3 g, 19.98 mmol) was suspended in dry DMF followed by the addition of sodium hydride (0.683 g, 29.97 mmol) and stirred under a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. cln_elements.content: 2-AP is known serve as a fluorescent nucleobase in biochemical studies. Chemical modifications of 2-AP and its interaction with metal ions afford interesting supramolecular architectures with variable photophysical properties. Consequently, fluorescence properties of ligands L1 and L2 and all complexes 1–5 were determined in solution state at room temperature (). Ligand as well as complexes 1–3 and complex 5 exhibited broad photoluminescence spectra with a maximum at 371 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. All metal complexes (1–5) displayed reduced intensity in their respective emission spectra compared to ligand L1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Study

2-AP is known serve as a fluorescent nucleobase in biochemical studies. Chemical modifications of 2-AP and its interaction with metal ions afford interesting supramolecular architectures with variable photophysical properties. Consequently, fluorescence properties of ligands L1 and L2 and all complexes 1-5 were determined in solution state at room temperature (). Ligand as well as complexes 1-3 and complex 5 exhibited broad photoluminescence spectra with a maximum at 371 nm upon excitation at 310 nm. All metal complexes (1-5) displayed reduced intensity in their respective emission spectra compared to ligand L1.
